column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=Motor 3 is started and rotation of platter 2 and workpiece 1 begun.
#Text=High pressure fluid is then supplied to abrasive jet 6 via supply line 9 along with abrasive from hopper 11.
#Text=Traverse system 7 sweeps abrasive jet 6 across the face of workpiece 1.
#Text=In operation abrasive jet 6 erodes workpiece 1 at a faster rate than it erodes the mask.
#Text=The process continues until workpiece 1 is milled to the desired depth or the mask is destroyed.
#Text=When the desired degree of milling is approached the pressure supplied to abrasive jet 6 is decreased.
#Text=It has been found that for example 20,000 psi is safe for an aluminum skin of 0.025 inch.
#Text=The mask can be formed by the same apparatus used to do the milling.
#Text=Using the apparatus of FIG. 1 it has been found that the relative velocity of jet 6 relative to workpiece 1 is the most important factor for precision milling.
#Text=The higher the relative velocity the less material is removed per pass and the higher the resolution of milling.
#Text=For high resolution milling the tangential speed should be greater than 2000 inches/minute.
#Text=Preferably, the speed should be greater than 8000 in.
#Text=/min.
#Text=Speeds as high as 100,000 in.
#Text=/min. will produce even better results.
#Text=The sweep rate should be selected such that jet 6 overlaps about 40% of the previous area of exposure.
#Text=The overlap may be altered slightly during operation avoid tracking and the formation of "lay" marks.
#Text=Satisfactory amounts of overlap vary between 40 and 80%.
#Text=The tangential velocity will be greater on the outside of workpiece 1 than at the area closer to the center of rotation.
#Text=Accordingly, to obtain a uniform depth pocket the rotational speed should be varied to obtain constant tangential velocity.
#Text=Due to the high speeds involved this is preferably done by computer.
#Text=Control of the sweep rate seperatly or in combination with the rotational speed provides a second manner to alter the profile of the milled pocket.

#Text=Alternatively, the stand off distance of abrasive jet 6 can be varied by manipulator 8 to control the rate of milling. this method can either be used to provide even cutting or compensate for alterations in tangential velocity due to workpiece 1's shape as described above.
#Text=After the milling process is completed it is desirable to shut valve 12 and cutoff the supply of abrasive to nozzle 6.
#Text=Sweeping nozzle 6 with only water supplied then provides an excellent cleaning of the newly machined surface.
#Text=This operation also removes any embedded abrasive particles.
#Text=FIG. 2 is a perspective view of the apparatus of a second embodiment of the invention.
#Text=This apparatus is particularly adapted to the milling of isogrid surfaces on materials having a single axis of symmetry able to be rotated.
#Text=Examples include disks, cylinders, cones and spheres.
#Text=The apparatus illustrated is a prototype milling center.
#Text=The components and parameters used are similar to commercial systems, this apparatus introduces several additional means to control milling not present in the FIG. 1 apparatus.
